structured_info.title_cn: 混合交通流中连接自动驾驶车辆专用车道的基本图建模
structured_info.title_en: Modeling the Fundamental Diagram of Mixed Traffic Flow With Dedicated Lanes for Connected Automated Vehicles
structured_info.abstract: To solve the problems of when to set up connected automated vehicles (CAVs) dedicated lanes and how many CAVs dedicated lanes to set up under different penetration rates of CAVs, this work focuses on modeling the fundamental diagram of mixed traffic flow with dedicated lanes for CAVs. Firstly, the car-following modes and their proportion of mixed traffic flow without and with CAVs dedicated lanes are analyzed. Secondly, the fundamental diagram of mixed traffic flow is derived based on car-following models to analyze the traffic capacity with and without CAVs dedicated lanes. Then, the relevant properties of the fundamental diagram with CAVs dedicated lanes are proposed and proved. Finally, the sensitivity of related parameters (e.g., CAVs penetration rate, time headway, and free-flow speed) in the fundamental diagram is discussed. Results show that (1) the increase of CAVs penetration rate and free-flow speed can improve the traffic capacity; (2) the design of smaller CAVs time headway benefits traffic capacity. Moreover, one and two CAVs dedicated lanes of three manual lanes are set to improve the traffic capacity to the greatest extent when the penetration rate of CAVs reaches 0.6 and 0.86, respectively. It is noteworthy that developing CAVs dedicated lanes under a reasonable CAVs penetration rate does not waste resources and increases traffic congestion while improving traffic capacity.
structured_info.methodology: The study analyzes car-following modes in mixed traffic flow with and without CAVs dedicated lanes, derives the fundamental diagram model based on car-following models, and evaluates the impact of CAVs dedicated lanes on traffic capacity under different penetration rates of CAVs. Theoretical analysis and simulation experiments are conducted to validate the proposed model.
structured_info.conclusion: The study concludes that setting CAVs dedicated lanes can significantly improve traffic capacity when the penetration rate of CAVs reaches certain thresholds (0.6 for one lane and 0.86 for two lanes). The increase in CAVs penetration rate and free-flow speed enhances traffic capacity, while smaller time headways for CAVs also benefit traffic capacity. The findings provide a theoretical basis for the application of CAVs dedicated lanes in transportation systems.
structured_info.venue: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems

analysis.Overview: The paper proposes a fundamental diagram model for mixed traffic flow with dedicated lanes for connected automated vehicles (CAVs). It analyzes car-following modes, derives the fundamental diagram, and evaluates the impact of CAVs dedicated lanes on traffic capacity under different penetration rates of CAVs.
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the challenges of integrating CAVs into existing traffic systems and optimizing the use of dedicated lanes for CAVs.
The motivation is to determine when and how many dedicated lanes for CAVs should be set up to improve traffic efficiency without wasting resources.
The authors argue for the necessity of dedicated lanes by highlighting the difficulties CAVs face in predicting human-driven vehicles' behavior, leading to traffic accidents.
The study relates the specific problem of CAVs integration to the broader challenge of improving traffic safety and efficiency in mixed traffic environments.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering, traffic flow theory, and intelligent transportation systems.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include car-following modes (C-H, C-C, H-C, H-H), fundamental diagram, and traffic capacity.
The logical relationship network involves analyzing how different car-following modes affect traffic flow and capacity.
Key assumptions include steady-state traffic conditions and the isolation of CAVs and human-driven vehicles on dedicated lanes.
The paper contributes a theoretical framework for modeling mixed traffic flow with CAVs dedicated lanes and provides insights into optimal lane management.
Methodology: The study uses car-following models to derive the fundamental diagram and analyzes traffic capacity with and without dedicated lanes.
The methodology is novel in its focus on dedicated lanes for CAVs and its applicability to real-world traffic management.
Data sources include theoretical models and simulation experiments in SUMO, with parameters consistent with real-world traffic conditions.
Experimental design includes sensitivity analysis of key parameters (penetration rate, time headway, free-flow speed).
The research follows the theoretical paradigm of traffic flow theory and uses microscopic and macroscopic traffic models.
Results: Key results show that traffic capacity increases with CAVs penetration rate and free-flow speed, and smaller time headways for CAVs improve capacity.
The results are reliable and stable, supported by simulation experiments and theoretical analysis.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The authors structure their argument by first analyzing car-following modes, then deriving the fundamental diagram, and finally evaluating the impact of dedicated lanes.
Key steps include modeling car-following behavior, deriving traffic capacity, and proving properties of the fundamental diagram.
Strengths include comprehensive analysis and validation through simulation. Weaknesses include assumptions like steady-state conditions, which may not always hold in real traffic.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths include the novel focus on CAVs dedicated lanes and the comprehensive theoretical and simulation analysis.
Limitations include the assumption of steady-state traffic and the exclusion of lane-changing behavior in the model.
The theoretical paradigm constrains conclusions by assuming ideal conditions, which may not fully capture real-world complexities.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper contributes to the discourse on CAVs integration and traffic flow management.
The authors use technical terminology and a formal tone, building authority through citations of relevant literature.
Citations are used to establish the significance of the research problem and to validate the proposed methodology.
Conclusions_and_Implications: The study concludes that setting dedicated lanes for CAVs at specific penetration rates can optimize traffic capacity.
Future research should validate the model with experimental data, consider different management strategies for dedicated lanes, and explore the impact on traffic safety and emissions.
